abstract.p: Dr Janice M Caulwels letter on July 18 article questions sterotypical standards of feminine thought and behavior stressed in program aimed at preventing eating disorders in girls

block.p: As presented by Dr. Beth Williams-Plunkett, the body image improvement program developed by Dr. Thomas E. Cash seems designed to replace low self-esteem with stereotypical standards of feminine thought and behavior (''A New Body Politic: Learning to Like the Way We Look,'' July 18). By telling impressionable adolescent girls that motherhood and breast feeding are ''one of the most wonderful things a woman's body can do for her,'' Dr. Williams-Plunkett implies that female worth is measured primarily by the desire and ability to reproduce and the choice of feeding method.

As presented by Dr. Beth Williams-Plunkett, the body image improvement program developed by Dr. Thomas E. Cash seems designed to replace low self-esteem with stereotypical standards of feminine thought and behavior (''A New Body Politic: Learning to Like the Way We Look,'' July 18). By telling impressionable adolescent girls that motherhood and breast feeding are ''one of the most wonderful things a woman's body can do for her,'' Dr. Williams-Plunkett implies that female worth is measured primarily by the desire and ability to reproduce and the choice of feeding method.
The message should place equal emphasis on all the body's capabilities and all the ways in which eating disorders damage health.
And along with assigning victims the responsibility for deflecting harmful messages, how about educating the fathers, brothers and other males who torment these girls?
DR. JANICE M. CAUWELS Maywood, N.J.
